Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Research in Biomathematics, Enumerative Combinatorics, Networks, and Statistics at Valparaiso University
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports the summer REU site Valparaiso Experience in Research by Undergraduate Mathematicians (VERUM). VERUM will recruit twelve undergraduate students each year. The students will work in teams of three, for nine weeks, on solving open problems in biomathematics, enumeration, networks, or statistics. Each group will work with a project director who will provide guidance and feedback to the students on a daily basis. Participants will investigate open questions of interest to the larger mathematical community, therefore yielding potentially publishable results. The program will provide undergraduates with a first research experience in mathematics. Most of the participants will be students from primarily undergraduate institutions who have not yet decided on a graduate school career path. Additional attention will be given to recruiting participants from groups under-represented in STEM, including first-generation college students. The award is supported by the Division of Mathematical Sciences (DMS) in the Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences (MPS) and the Division of Biological Infrastructure (DBI) in the Directorate for Biological Sciences (BIO).

By modeling the research experience of a mathematician, the program will produce students engaged with, and prepared to join, the mathematical community. The program emphasizes the professional development of the students while encouraging them to pursue mathematically related careers and graduate studies, thus increasing the participation of traditionally underrepresented groups in STEM disciplines. Students will become part of a small professional group that will provide support during their undergraduate careers and beyond. As part of the program, students will visit graduate schools to learn about the experiences of graduate students in different types of institutions. Students will also be exposed to different areas of mathematics by following the progress of each research group and by listening to, and interacting with, weekly visitors to the program. VERUM participants will increase their communication and presentation skills through weekly group presentations, presentations at local and national conferences, and through writing a final project report.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Valparaiso Experience in Research by Undergraduate Mathematicians program provides an opportunity for undergraduate participants to model the research experience of a mathematician.  The program serves students with limited access to a research environment and helps these students foster effective work habits.  Students work closely with a project mentor and have increased independence in their work as the program progresses.  There is also a strong professional development component with a focus on improved written and oral communication of technical material throughout the summer program.

Over the life of this grant, 37 undergraduate students were supported to conduct research projects under the guidance of Valparaiso University faculty.  Twelve students participated in cohorts for each of summers 2017, 2018, and 2019.  One additional student was supported in summer 2020.  Each summer, these students were selected from a national applicant pool with particular consideration given to applicants for whom the program was a first research experience.  Our stated objectives also included the involvement of students that come from a population traditionally underrepresented in the mathematical sciences.  53% of the participants were female, 22% first generation college students, and 22% minority students.

Students met daily with their faculty mentors in small groups to discuss progress on their research projects, which varied across disciplines such as enumerative combinatorics, graphs and network theory, statistics, and biomathematics.

Weekly guest lecturers helped expose students to a variety of research topics and mathematical career options.  Each summer, visitors included mathematicians from academia, industry, and government, to assure that the participants could explore a wide range of possible career paths.  In addition to research areas, the participants also learned about possible funding opportunities for future studies and professional development in mathematics.  Students also visited two graduate schools and met with faculty and graduate students to learn more about graduate work in mathematics.  Based on annual assessment of the program, most participants were more likely to consider graduate school in mathematics as a career option at the end of the program than at the beginning of the program.

Students gave weekly presentations to their peers and faculty mentors on their work; by the end of the program, each student teach produces slides for a 20-minute talk and a research poster to disseminate their work at appropriate conferences.  Each year, students attended a state-wide undergraduate mathematics conference where each group gave an oral presentation.  Each project was also presented in January following the summer at the Joint Mathematics Meetings in the undergraduate poster session.  Many of the participants disseminated results at their own institutions and at other local and regional mathematics conferences.  As of July 2021, seven scientific papers have been published from the results of these projects, with one additional paper submitted and two in preparation for publication.  All final project reports are also available at https://www.valpo.edu/mathematics-statistics/verum-summer-research-program/completed-verum-projects/.

Of the 35 participants who have graduated so far, 20 have begun or will begin graduate studies in a mathematics-related discipline by fall 2021, two have begun careers as teachers, and at least five are mathematically employed in actual science or in the technology sector.
